questions.text:
A woman with persistent asthma, comes to establish antenatal care after positive pregnancy test. For adequate control, her regimen was increased to daily medium dose ICS and as-needed salbutamol last month. What should she be advised regarding asthma management during pregnancy?

ICS : Inhaled corticosteroids

choices.text: Decrease dose to low dose ICS

questions.solution:
Drugs such as inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) and short acting beta-2 adrenergic agonists (SABAs) are safe to use in pregnancy and can be continued without any modification.

Poor asthma control may have adverse effects on fetal development. SABAs, ICS and theophylline have been shown to be safe, and are not teratogenic. Although, safety information concerning newer classes of drugs (LABAs, antileukotriene inhibitors and anti-IgE antibodies) are lacking they are recommended for use. There is also no contraindication during breastfeeding.

Early asthma stages are well tolerated by healthy non-pregnant women but may be dangerous for pregnant women and the fetus, as the diminished functional residual capacity and greater pulmonary shunting makes the mother susceptible to hypoxia and hypoxemia. 

If the patient has daytime symptoms up to 2 times per week, and nighttime awakenings up to 2 times per month it is called intermittent asthma. If the symptoms are more severe, then the patient has persistent asthma. Persistent asthma is further classified based on symptom severity:

Category Daytime symptoms Nighttime awakening Treatment
    Mild persistent     More than 2 times per week but less than daily 3-4 times a month but not every week Low dose ICS + formoterol as needed
Moderate persistent Daily Once per week Low dose ICS + formoterol daily
Severe persistent Present throughout the day along with severe restriction of daily activities Almost every night Medium to high dose ICS + formoterol/LABA daily + add-on drugs

Inhaled corticosteroid is the first line of treatment in patients with persistent asthma. As per Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) guidelines, formoterol + low-dose ICS is the preferred reliever in all cases of asthma. SABAs are alternative relievers to manage all cases of asthma.

Other options:

Option C: The dosage of ICS should be decreased if symptoms are controlled after 3 months. This patient’s dosage was recently increased 1 month ago.

Related Pearl: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms (GINA-2022)

Asthma management - GINA 2022

questions.text: A patient was treated with an intravenous antimalarial drug following which he developed tinnitus, headache, nausea, and visual disturbances. Examination revealed hypotension and lab reports revealed hypoglycemia. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of the adverse effects of quinine. It is an antimalarial used to treat severe malaria.

Quinine is used in the treatment of drug-resistant and severe P. falciparum malaria. It acts against asexual erythrocytic forms of malarial parasites. 

Quinine is most commonly associated with a triad of adverse effects which includes:

  • Cinchonism - headache, tinnitus, high-tone deafness, visual disturbances, vomiting, and postural hypotension.
  • Hypoglycemia - results due to hyperinsulinemia secondary to stimulation of pancreatic beta cells by quinine.
  • Hypotension.

Other adverse effects of quinine include gastrointestinal disturbance, skin manifestations (sweating, flushing, rash, and angioedema), QTc prolongation, and blackwater fever.

Blackwater fever is a hypersensitivity reaction associated with the use of quinine. It presents with a triad of severe hemolysis, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria.

Other options:

Options A and B: Artemether and artesunate cause gastrointestinal disturbances, itching, drug fever, and hypersensitivity reactions. Minor adverse effects include headache, dizziness, and dark urine.

Option D: Atovaquone can cause gastrointestinal side effects like abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. It can also cause transient elevation of serum amylase or transaminase.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl was brought with complaints of vomiting and altered consciousness. She was recently diagnosed with an influenza infection and was started on an antipyretic for fever. Laboratory tests showed increased levels of liver enzymes but normal serum bilirubin levels. What could have been the prescribed antipyretic in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical history suggests an adverse reaction to the given antipyretic medication and describes Reye's syndrome. Reye's syndrome can be precipitated in children with viral infection and concomitant use of salicylates like aspirin.

Reye syndrome is an acute encephalopathy that may follow a viral upper respiratory tract infection (influenza or varicella). It is precipitated in a genetically susceptible person by the interaction between viral infection and exposure to salicylates and/or antiemetics.

Clinically children present with acute onset vomiting and features of encephalopathy like delirium, altered consciousness, confusion, and lethargy.

Liver dysfunction is present in all cases and presents with coagulopathy and laboratory evidence of elevated serum levels of aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase, and ammonia. But, bilirubin levels remain normal and the patient does not develop jaundice.

A biopsy of the liver in a patient with Reye's syndrome shows microvesicular infiltration of fat in the hepatocytes. Reye syndrome is a life-threatening adverse effect, and patients must also be screened for fatty acid oxidation and fatty acid transport defects.

Another salicylate medication that risks the development of Reye's syndrome is bismuth subsalicylate.

Other options:

Mefenamic acid, ibuprofen, and acetaminophen are non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs that can be used as antipyretics in children and are not associated with the development of Reye's syndrome.

questions.text:
You are posted as an intern in the medicine ward where your consultant asks you to make a list of all the patients who require strict therapeutic drug monitoring. All the following patients will be included in your list, except ______.
  1. Epileptic patient on phenytoin
  2. Hypertensive patient on long-term thiazide
  3. Bipolar patient on lithium
  4. Parkinsonism patient on levodopa
  5. Diabetic patient on metformin
questions.solution:
Option B is correct. Thiazide, levodopa, and metformin do not require therapeutic drug monitoring. However, phenytoin and lithium will require strict therapeutic drug monitoring because of their narrow therapeutic window.

Therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) is individualizing drug dosage by maintaining plasma or blood drug concentrations within a targeted therapeutic range or window.

Indications for TDM:

  1. Drugs with low safety margins i.e. narrow therapeutic window (e.g. digoxin, anticonvulsants, antiarrhythmics, theophylline, aminoglycosides, lithium, TCAs, immunomodulators)
  2. Drugs with high individual variations (e.g. lithium, antidepressants)
  3. Drugs with potential toxicity used in renal failure patients (e.g. aminoglycosides, vancomycin)
  4. Poisoning
  5. Drug therapy failure (e.g. failure of response to antibiotics)
  6. To check patient compliance (e.g. psycho-pharmacological agents)

TDM is not necessary for

  1. Drugs whose response is easily measured (eg. antihypertensives, anti-diabetic agents, oral anticoagulants, inhalational general anesthesia)
  2. Prodrugs (e.g. levodopa)
  3. Drugs that have long-lasting effects -Hit and run drugs e.g. reserpine, guanethidine, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, omeprazole)
  4. Irreversible action of drugs (eg. organophosphates, phenoxybenzamine)

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants

questions.text: A patient is prescribed dextromethorphan for cough. Which of the following is mechanism by which it exerts its actions and its adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Dextromethorphan is a centrally-acting NMDA receptor antagonist that is used as an antitussive. One of its major side effects is hallucinations at high doses.

Antitussives are a group of drugs that acts centrally to raise the threshold of the cough center or peripherally on the respiratory tract to reduce the tussal impulse or both.

The antitussive action of dextromethorphan is due to the d-isomer form. It is used in children above the age of 6 and in adults for cough suppression. It also antagonizes opioid receptors. (Option A and C)

Hallucinations at higher doses as well as abuse potential are its side effects. It has very little associated constipation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman gave birth to a child with the features shown in the given image. On examination, the child had brittle bones, and x-ray scans revealed stippled epiphyses. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be implicated in causing this teratogenic condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a depressed nasal bridge (saddle nose). This image along with the stippling of bone epiphyses points to fetal warfarin syndrome or warfarin embryopathy. 

Features:

  • Repeated abortions
  • CNS abnormalities
  • Depressed nasal bridge/absent nasal bone/saddle nose at birth
  • Bleeding diathesis at birth
  • Growth retardation - hypoplasia of nose, eye sockets, and long bones with stippling of epiphyses 

Anticoagulation in pregnancy:

  • Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, it can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths.
  • Heparin: It is safe for the fetus but is less effective than warfarin.
  • LMWH: It is inadequate, and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves.

Period of gestation

Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

LMWH or UFH

13 to 36 weeks

Warfarin

36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery

LMWH or UFH

6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section

LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

If delivery occurs while the anticoagulant is still effective, and excessive bleeding happens, then protamine sulfate is given intravenously. 

Anticoagulation of pregnant women:

  • The patient taking warfarin should discontinue it as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed and replace it with heparin 5,000 units twice daily subcutaneously up to the 12th week of gestation. 
  • Heparin is then replaced by a warfarin tablet of 3 mg daily to be taken at the same time each day and continued up to 36 weeks in patients with a high risk of thrombosis.
  • Thereafter, warfarin is replaced by heparin, which is discontinued 6 hours just before delivery.
  • Heparin (unfractionated or LMWH) is restarted 6 hours after vaginal delivery and 24 hours after the cesarean section.
  • Unfractionated heparin (UFH), LMWH, and warfarin therapy are not contraindicated in breastfeeding.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is started on tofacitinib. What is the mechanism of action for this drug?
questions.solution:
Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK 1/3 - Inhibitor which will inhibit the JAK-STAT pathway responsible for the production of cytokines and chemokines. It has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis, and is also used in rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis.

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with complaints of a runny nose and multiple bouts of sneezing. He has had such symptoms on and off since childhood and his symptoms worsen in the spring and when he goes out of the house. He is given a drug that has the action of leukotriene receptor antagonism for his condition. Which among the following drugs is the drug given to the patient?
questions.solution:
Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists. 

The leukotrienes are proinflammatory mediators produced from arachidonic acid via the 5-lipoxygenase (5-LO) pathway. These drugs are competitive antagonists of the cys LT1 receptor and hence decrease bronchoconstriction, airway mucus secretion, increased vascular permeability, and recruitment of eosinophil.

This patient with symptoms of runny nose and multiple bouts of sneezing along with worsening of his symptoms in spring and outside environment strongly suggests allergic rhinitis as the diagnosis.

Uses: 

Montelukast and Zafirlukast are indicated for the treatment of allergic rhinitis. Antileukotrienes are useful in preventing exercise-induced asthma. They act mainly by inhibiting bronchoconstriction.

In some patients, anti leukotriene agents are effective as monotherapy in the treatment of mild to moderate persistent asthma, although the mean efficacy of anti leukotriene agents is lower than that of inhaled glucocorticoids (IGCs). Thus, IGCs are preferred first-line controller agents, and anti leukotriene agents are considered alternatives, particularly in patients who have difficulty with adherence or inhaler technique.

Adverse effects:

  • Zileuton, montelukast, and zafirlukast are all associated with rare cases of hepatic dysfunction. Hence, liver function tests should be monitored during the course of their therapy.
  • Churg-Strauss syndrome consisting of vasculitis with eosinophilia is associated with the use of montelukast and zafirlukast. 

Other options:

Option A- Ketotifen is a mast cell stabilizer used for the management of bronchial asthma and allergic disorders such as atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis/conjunctivitis, and chronic urticaria. Oral ketotifen possesses both anti-mediator and mast cell-stabilizing properties.

Option B- Cromolyn sodium is a mast cell stabilizer. It inhibits the release of mediators of inflammation, including histamine and leukotrienes, from the mast cells that are induced by reactive antigens that result in allergic symptoms and bronchoconstriction.

Option D- Zileuton is a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor and helps to reduce inflammation, edema, mucus secretion, and bronchoconstriction in the airways.

questions.text: A patient develops a postoperative wound discharge. The culture of the discharge reveals infection with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Which of the following cephalosporins can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ceftaroline, which is considered as anti-MRSA cephalosporin, is indicated for MRSA infections and can, therefore, be used in this patient. It is grouped as fifth-generation cephalosporins along with ceftobiprole.

Ceftaroline has gram-negative and also enhanced gram-positive coverage. It is effective against MRSA and penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Other options:

Option A: Ceftizoxime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is less active against S. pneumoniae and more active against Bacteroides fragilis. It has no action on MRSA.

Option B: Cefpirome is a fourth-generation cephalosporin that has antipseudomonal activity and activity against many organisms, such as Enterobacter and Pseudomonas, that are resistant to other cephalosporins, with no significant action on MRSA.

Option C: Ceftolozane is an anti-pseudomonal cephalosporin that is a structural analog of ceftazidime. It has enhanced activity against Pseudomonas, including activity against strains resistant to ceftazidime through β-lactamase overexpression, with no action on MRSA.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text:
A patient has been taking ramipril to control his hypertension for the past 10 years. On a recent follow-up visit, the doctor advised the addition of one more antihypertensive drug to his regimen. Which of the following drugs cannot be prescribed to this patient?

1. Spironolactone
2. Metolazone
3. Triamterene
4. Amiloride
5. Chlorthalidone
questions.solution:
Spironolactone, triamterene, and amiloride (1, 3, and 4) should not be prescribed to patients taking ramipril. Ramipril is an ACE inhibitor, and if it is taken along with potassium-sparing diuretics, it may lead to hyperkalemia. 

K+ sparing diuretics work by 2 mechanisms:

  • Blocking the ENaC (epithelial sodium channel) in the late distal tubules.
    • Triamterene
    • Amiloride
  • Aldosterone receptor antagonist
    • Spironolactone
    • Eplerenone
    • Canrenone

Thiazides and loop diuretics may lead to loss of potassium and cause hypokalemia. Metolazone and chlorthalidone are thiazides and can be given along with ACE inhibitors.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female who was on a antihypertensive now came with complaints of swelling and redness of her great toe. Lab investigations show hyperuricemia along with hypokalemia and hypocalcemia. What could be the drug leading to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with lab findings of hypokalemia and hypocalcemia is suggestive of gout secondary to the use of furosemide.

Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. Hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, hyperuricemia, and hypomagnesemia are the important side effects. 

Other options:

Option B: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that acts by inhibiting the Na-Cl symporter in the distal convoluted tubule resulting in increased excretion of sodium and chloride. Hydrochlorothiazide results in hypokalemia and hypercalcemia, whereas this patient presents with hypocalcemia. Other findings include hyperuricemia and hypomagnesemia.

Option C:  Losartan is the angiotensin receptor blocker used for the treatment of hypertension. Hyperkalemia is an important side effect of ARBs. Losartan appears to be a safe and efficacious agent to lower serum uric acid levels in patients with hyperuricemia.

Option D: Spironolactone belongs to potassium-sparing diuretics and causes hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A schizophrenia patient is being delivered olanzapine by a Z-track technique. From the given images, identify the route of injection in which the Z-track technique is used.
questions.solution:
Route A shows the intramuscular administration of medication and the Z track technique is used for this route of administration.

Procedure:

  • Stretch the skin by pulling it laterally away from the intended point of injection.
  • Insert the needle into the site at a 90˚angle, aspirate by pulling back to see if the needle has a penetrated vessel.
  • If blood is aspirated withdraw the needle, and repeat the procedure at another site with new equipment and medication.
  • If no blood is aspirated administer the injection.
  • Wait for 10 seconds and then withdraw the needle, and release the skin allowing the displaced tissue to seal the needle track.


Other options:

1. Intravenous injection (Figure C) e.g. injection ferric carboxymaltose

2. Subcutaneous injection (Figure B) e.g. injection insulin glargine

3. Intra-dermal route (Figure D) e.g. injection platelet-activating factor

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with hypertension, diabetes, and ischemic heart disease undergoes percutaneous coronary intervention with the placement of a drug-eluting stent in order to reduce restenosis. Which of the following is involved in the further care of this patient?

choices.text: Daily aspirin for 6 months then daily clopidogrel for 6 months
Daily aspirin indefinitely and clopidogrel for at least 1 year
Daily aspirin for 1 year and clopidogrel for 6 months

questions.solution:
Clopidogrel, a P2Y12 receptor blocker, along with aspirin is called dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT). DAPT should be continued for at least 1 year following stent placement to prevent stent thrombosis, with aspirin being continued indefinitely. 

Drug-eluting stents (DES) are coronary stents that locally release antiproliferative agents that can reduce restenosis. However, the delayed endothelial healing in the region of the stent can increase the acute risk of thrombosis during the period after placement. This increased risk calls for the use of dual antiplatelet therapy for at least a year. The commonly used antiproliferative drugs in DES are everolimus, tacrolimus, sirolimus, paclitaxel, etc.

questions.text: A female patient on oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) was prescribed phenytoin after she developed seizures. What is the main concern here?

choices.text: Phenytoin is an enzyme inducer and causes failure of OCPs.
Phenytoin is an enzyme inhibitor and causes failure of OCPs.
Phenytoin is an enzyme inducer and causes OCP toxicity.
Phenytoin is an enzyme inhibitor and causes OCP toxicity.

questions.solution:
Phenytoin is an enzyme inducer and can cause the failure of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs).

Phenytoin can induce various hepatic CYPs. OCPs are metabolized by CYP3A4. Hence, the administration of phenytoin in a patient who is on OCPs results in enhanced metabolism of OCPs. This may lead to an unplanned pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient presented to the primary health center with symptoms of sneezing, runny nose, and red, itchy, watery eyes. He was prescribed azelastine after being diagnosed with allergic rhinitis. Select the preferred formulation of the drug in this patient.
questions.solution:
The preferred formulation of azelastine in this patient would be an intranasal spray. 

Azelastine is a second-generation antihistamine that has good topical activity. It is available as a nasal spray for treating symptoms of allergic or vasomotor rhinitis and is also available as an ophthalmic solution for allergic conjunctivitis.

On intranasal application, it downregulates ICAM-1 expression on the nasal mucosa. It has a long duration of action and is administered as a nasal spray to provide relief in cases of allergic rhinitis, with its effect lasting for up to 12 hours.

On local application, it can cause altered taste perception and stinging in the nose while oral administration can also result in weight gain. The metabolism of azelastine is inhibited by CYP3A4 inhibitors.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient, who is a known case of chronic hypertension, delivers a male baby by vaginal delivery. Following the delivery, she starts to bleed profusely. All of the following medications can be used to control hemorrhage in this patient, except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario indicates postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in this patient following vaginal delivery. All of the listed medications can be used for management, except methylergonovine. Methergine (methylergonovine) is contraindicated in a patient with a history of chronic hypertension.  

Ergot alkaloids (ergonovine and methylergonovine) are commonly used second-line agents to treat uterine atony if atony persists despite oxytocin and other preventive measures. Given oral or parenterally, these drugs act rapidly and cause strong uterine contraction. However, ergot agents may cause dangerous hypertension, which is more likely in women with preeclampsia or chronic hypertension. Other contraindications include organic heart disease, multifetal pregnancy after delivery of the first twin, and sepsis. 

Oxytocin is used as the first-line agent in preventing postpartum hemorrhage. If bleeding and atony are refractory, a second-line agent can be added. These include:

  • Ergot alkaloids, namely methylergonovine and ergonovine
  • Carboprost tromethamine, the 15-methyl derivative of prostaglandin F2α. However, it is contraindicated in asthmatics and patients with pulmonary hypertension. It can also cause systemic hypertension as a side effect and should be used with caution in hypertensive patients.
  • Misoprostol, a synthetic prostaglandin E1 analogue. It is contraindicated in patients with previous cesarean section. 
  • Inj. tranexamic acid, an antifibrinolytic agent

questions.text: A newborn cannot breastfeed as he vomits and chokes each time he attempts to feed. He also has other anomalies including radial aplasia, vertebral anomalies and anal defects. An NG tube is attempted to be pushed in and an X-ray of the same is seen below. Which of the following drugs is likely to have been taken by the mother during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The x-ray in the question shows that the NG tube cannot pass through to the stomach. This along with the other anomalies mentioned makes a diagnosis of Tracheoesophageal fistula the likely diagnosis. This child has VACTERL deformities. The drug group associated with this is the statin group of drugs. 

VACTERL defect is an acronym for a group of congenital malformations that characteristically include:

  • Vertebral defects
  • Anal atresia
  • Cardiovascular malformation
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula with esophageal atresia
  • Radial/Renal dysplasia
  • Limb anomalies

Genito-urinary anomalies (ambiguous genitalia, genitourinary fistula, cryptorchidism) and other system anomalies, such as facial asymmetry and external ear malformation, can also be found in these patients.

VACTERL defects have been associated with maternal exposure to statins, doxorubicin, and lead. They are also associated with maternal diabetes.

Other options

Option A: Warfarin is safe and effective in preventing thromboembolism in the mother during the 2nd trimester. However, it is teratogenic and can lead to miscarriage, stillbirths, fetal anticoagulation, hypoplastic nasal structures and fetal embryopathy if used in the 1st trimester.

Option C: Hypoplasia of organs, anuria, and irreversible renal failure are associated with ACE inhibitor intake during pregnancy.

Option D: The fetus of a pregnant woman who is on phenytoin is at the greatest risk of developing fetal hydantoin syndrome. Features of fetal hydantoin syndrome include:

  • Craniofacial anomalies (such as upturned nose, midfacial hypoplasia, and long upper lip with thin vermilion border)
  • Fingernail hypoplasia
  • Developmental delay
  • Orofacial clefts
  • Cardiac anomalies
  • Growth deficiency

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and a recent history of diarrhea. He has associated tenderness over the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Abdominal CT is shown below. Which of the following drugs is indicated for the management of the CT finding?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fever, abdominal pain, a recent history of diarrhea, and an abdominal CT showing a moderate-sized abscess in the right liver lobe is suggestive of an amebic liver abscess. It is an extra-intestinal infection caused by Entamoeba histolytica and metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating this condition. 

Amebic liver abscess follows intestinal amebiasis. However, a history of diarrhea may not always be present as most patients remain asymptomatic carriers. In patients presenting with the above symptoms, stool examination, serological tests, and radiological imaging help to confirm the diagnosis. 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating invasive amebiasis like an amebic liver abscess. It is a nitroimidazole compound and is a highly active tissue amebicide. Tinidazole, which is another longer-acting imidazole, is also highly effective for the management of this condition. Other tissue amebicides include secnidazole, satranidazole and ornidazole.

Metronidazole is also effective against other anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms. It is used in the management of giardiasis, trichomoniasis, anaerobic bacterial infections (e.g., pelvic or abdominal abscesses following surgery), pseudomembranous enterocolitis, and Helicobacter pylori gastritis.

Adverse effects include gastrointestinal manifestations like anorexia, nausea, and a metallic taste. It is known for its ability to produce a disulfiram-like reaction when taken with alcohol. Metronidazole can decrease the renal elimination of lithium and potentiate its toxicity. It may also cause significant bleeding in patients on warfarin therapy.

Other options:

Iodoquinol (Option B), paromomycin (Option C), and diloxanide furoate (Option D) are luminal amebicides. They are poorly absorbed and thus reach high concentrations in the bowel and are used in the management of intestinal amebiasis. They are also indicated for invasive amebiasis. However, their role is to eradicate cysts and prevent further transmission. They would not have any direct effect on the extraintestinal liver abscess as seen in this case.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency for the alleged consumption of an organophosphate compound. He is being treated with atropine and develops palpitations, blurring of vision, dryness of mouth, difficulty in speaking and swallowing, and difficulty in micturition. All of the following antihistamines can safely administered in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient being treated with atropine developing palpitations, blurring or vision and dryness of mouth,  difficulty in speaking and swallowing, and difficulty in micturition are indicative of atropine toxicity. Promethazine should be avoided in this case.

Promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine that has the strongest antimuscarinic activity amongst all antihistamines and therefore can potentiate atropine toxicity. Therefore, it has to be avoided in this patient.

A few important symptoms of atropine toxicity are shown in the diagram below.

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)

  • Diarrhea
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm
  • Bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation
  • Sweating

Nicotinic manifestations include twitching of eyelids, tongue, and facial muscles which then leads to paralysis. CNS stimulation results in headaches, tremors, ataxia, coma, and death. 

Other options:

Options A, B, and D: Fexofenadine, loratadine, and levocetrizine are second-generation antihistamines with no anticholinergic activity and therefore can safely be used in this patient.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man develops pulmonary tuberculosis and is started on ATT. After a year, he develops a sudden decrease in vision of both eyes. On examination, vision in both eyes is 3/60. He finds it difficult to read Ishihara’s chart. He also has pain while moving his eyeballs. On fundus examination, the discs and vessels were normal. What is the most probable drug which can be implicated in this complication?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis, as the patient has a sudden deterioration in his vision, painful extraocular movements, and poor color discrimination. The antitubercular drug, ethambutol can cause retrobulbar neuritis and red-green color blindness.

Optic neuritis resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of ability to differentiate red from green is the most serious adverse effect of ethambutol. It is a dose-dependent adverse effect that can be unilateral or bilateral. The intensity of the visual difficulty is related to the duration of therapy.

Tests of visual acuity and red-green discrimination before the start of therapy and periodically thereafter are recommended.

Ethambutol is used for the treatment of tuberculosis, disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex, and Mycobacterium kansasii infection. It inhibits arabinosyl transferase III, thereby disrupting the transfer of arabinose into arabinogalactan biosynthesis. This disrupts the assembly of the mycobacterial cell wall. Resistance occurs due to mutations in the embB gene.

Since 80% of the drug is eliminated through the kidney unchanged, its dosing should be decreased in renal failure to avoid toxicity. Ethambutol should be given 15-25 mg/kg three times a week, instead of daily in patients with renal failure.

Other side effects are pruritus, joint pain, GI upset, abdominal pain, malaise, headache, dizziness, mental confusion, disorientation, possible hallucinations, and decreased renal excretion of uric acid.
